case_vignette:
A 30 year old male is admitted to the hospital for a rash that developed on the chest and then spread across the back, face, and legs. He recently started lamotrigine two weeks ago for seizure prevention. He denies any other recent medication changes. He endorses significant pain at the site of the rash and also pain with urination.   Physical examination reveals diffuse pink erythematous patches of the chest, back with few scattered dusky central patches and multiple bullae. Applying pressure with a finger and moving laterally results in separation of the skin on many areas of the back. Oral erosions on the lips and on the glans penis are appreciated.   The patient is diagnosed with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The patient is transferred to the burn unit for further care.

A 30 year old female is admitted to the hospital for a rash that developed on the chest and then spread across the back, face, and legs. She recently started lamotrigine two weeks ago for seizure prevention. She denies any other recent medication changes. She endorses significant pain at the site of the rash and also pain with urination.   Physical examination reveals diffuse pink erythematous patches of the chest, back with few scattered dusky central patches and multiple bullae. Applying pressure with a finger and moving laterally results in separation of the skin on many areas of the back. Oral erosions on the lips and on the vulva are appreciated.   The patient is diagnosed with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The patient is transferred to the burn unit for further care.

trial_0.vignette_frq: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful rash that started on my chest and spread to my back, face, and legs, along with pain during urination.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for about two weeks.
Have you noticed any blisters or open sores associated with the rash?
Yes, there are multiple blisters on the rash areas.
Do the blisters have any fluid in them, and if so, what color is the fluid?
Yes, the blisters are filled with fluid, but I am not sure about the color.
Have you recently started any new medications or been diagnosed with any new medical conditions?
Yes, I recently started taking lamotrigine two weeks ago for seizure prevention.
Final Diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome

Additionally, the patient experiences pain during urination. These symptoms have been present for approximately two weeks. The patient notes that there are multiple blisters on the affected areas; these blisters are fluid-filled, though the color of the fluid is unclear. Furthermore, the patient started taking lamotrigine two weeks ago for seizure prevention.
